author: Olivier Brueckner
description: A weird story, influenced by old German names and Zelda foes.
code:
// require /text/tracery.min.js

const storyGrammar = {
  story: [
    "It was a dark and stormy night. #phrase.capitalize#. Meanwhile, #phrase#. #phrase.capitalize#. #expression.capitalize#. #endphrase.capitalize# We will never knowâ€¦",
  ],
  phrase: ["#subject# #duoverb# #object.a#"],
  expression: [
    "'Watch out!', shouted #subject#",
    "'What is that?', asked #subject#",
    "#subject# laughed",
  ],
  endphrase: ["Is this what #subject# #soloverb.ed#?"],
  subject: [
    "#noun.a#",
    "#adjective.a# #noun#",
    "#name#, the #adjective# #noun#,",
  ],
  object: [
    "#noun#",
    "#adjective# #noun#",
    "#adjective# #noun# and #adverb.a# #adjective# #noun#",
  ],

  adverb: [
    "exceptionally",
    "somewhat",
    "beautifully",
    "foolishly",
    "judgmentally",
  ],
  // add some eerie adjectives
  adjective: [
    "scary",
    "small",
    "big",
    "uncanny ",
    "strange  ",
    "frightening  ",
    "ghostly  ",
    "weird  ",
    "mysterious  ",
    "scary",
    "sinister  ",
    "uneasy  ",
    "fearful  ",
    "awesome  ",
    "unearthly  ",
    "supernatural  ",
    "unnatural  ",
    "spooky",
    "creepy",
    "spectral  ",
    "eldritch",
    "preternatural  ",
  ],
  // add some weird old german names
  name: [
    "Peter",
    "RÃ¼diger",
    "Gunhilde",
    "Hans",
    "Heribert",
    "Walter",
    "Frieda",
  ],
  // add some typical mythological animals and Zelda enemies
  noun: [
    "raven",
    "ghost",
    "bird",
    "witch",
    "cat",
    "moblin",
    "keese",
    "stalfos",
    "skulltula",
    "Deku Scrub",
    "octorok",
    "poe",
    "stalchild",
    "dodongo",
    "lizalfos",
    "gibdo",
  ],
  duoverb: [
    "looks at",
    "finds",
    "summons",
    "plots with",
    "has a drink with",
    "dances with",
    "glares at",
    "wonders about",
    "hides from",
    "plays catch with",
  ],
  soloverb: ["want", "create", "estimate", "expect", "guess", "ask", "book"],
};

const generateStory = () => {
  const grammar = tracery.createGrammar(storyGrammar);
  const story = grammar.flatten("#story#");

  const storyDiv = document.createElement("div");
  storyDiv.style = "font-size: 30px; margin: 10%; line-height: 1.5;"; // font-family: 'Papyrus'";
  storyDiv.textContent = story;

  document.body.insertAdjacentElement("beforeend", storyDiv);
};

setTimeout(generateStory, 10);

<canvas id="myCanvas" resize></canvas>
<script type="text/paperscript" canvas="myCanvas">
  for (var i = 0; i < 10; i++) {

	var from = new Point(20 * i, 20);
	var to = new Point(20 * i, 500);
	var path1 = new Path.Line(from, to);
	path1.strokeColor = '#AFE0FC';
	path1.strokeWidth = 10;
	path1.blendMode = 'multiply';


	var from = new Point(30 * i, 20);
	var to = new Point(40 * i, 500);
	var path2 = new Path.Line(from, to);
	path2.strokeColor = '#60ABFC';
	path2.strokeWidth = 10;
	path2.blendMode = 'lighter';


	var from = new Point(40 * i, 20);
	var to = new Point(30 * i, 500);
	var path3 = new Path.Line(from, to);

}

author: Tsung Han / Billy Ho
description:
(Group 5)

time.is : https://time.is/



## What youâ€™ll need:

Choose one of the following approaches:

**Approach A:** 

Any form of digital canvas(Figma, illustrator...)

**Approach B:** 

1. A pen (color of your choice)
2. A timekeeping device that shows the seconds (link to one of those sites in the description)
3. Piece of paper

## Instructions:

1. Draw a small square (somewhere **between 1cm^2** and **0.5 inch^2**) in the **middle** of the paper (doesnâ€™t have to be precise!)
2. Check the time, if the second right now is:
    1. Lower than **31** (not including **31**) â‡’ **color/fill** it.
    2. All the other numbers â‡’ leave it with just the stroke.
3. Check the time again, if the second right now is:
    1. Between **0** and **14** (including both ends) â‡’ Start a new square at the **top right** corner of the current square.
    2. Between **15** and **29** (including both ends) â‡’ Start a new square at the **bottom right** corner of the current square.
    3. Between **30** and **44** (including both ends) â‡’ Start a new square at the **bottom left** corner of the current square.
    4. Between **45** and **59** (including both ends) â‡’ Start a new square at the **top left** corner of the current square.
4. Repeat 2, 3 at least 9 more times and until youâ€™re satisfied, go to step 2 one last time. 

- If overlaps with previous squares, check:
    - if itâ€™s already filled â‡’ Leave it and continue to step 3.
    - if it isnâ€™t filled â‡’ Continue to Step 2.

comments.comment: Super cool! Just curious, why there are always an underscore in front of the variables?
Just my personal habit. I'm used to adding an underscore in front of each global variable to distinguish them from other local variables.

that's not a common habbit, but naming convention for classes of variables is a good idea.

i often do global variables in ALL_CAPS

i was using snake_case for variable names for a while, because i like it better, but most javascript is in camelCase

starting with _underscore is usually used to indicate something is informally private. (actual private members are new in js)

author: Yang ("Zhao Yang") Zhao
description:
***Yang's Sketch Instructions for Group 1: Connecting Dots***
----
(1). Start from the top of your page and draw 5 x 5 evenly spaced dots that resemble a grid. 
(2). Start with a random dot and connect it with an immediately neighboring dot (can be diagonal) in one line.
(3). Repeat (2) and make sure all dots are connected and the line is ***not*** crossed.
(4). Start from another position on your page and repeat (1), (2), (3)  to create a ***different*** line path.
(5). Repeat (4) until you are bored or exhaust all possible paths.

**Tips:** make the 5x5 grid smaller so you can fit more paths in one page. You can draw this in Figma/Adobe Creative Suite or other softwares or code. It doesnâ€™t need to be hand drawn on paper.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
Took a run at coding Yang Zhao's instructions. These instructions are mostly _procedural_. They describe the steps to perform. But they also mix in _declarative_ rules. They specify the results rather than the method. 

In particular "make sure all dots are connected and the line is not crossed" isn't easy to do! I settled for never visiting the same dot twice. I haven't added checks for crossed lines and I haven't added back tracking when you get stuck in a corner to try a different path.

Also worth noting that in addition to procedural and declarative bits, Zhao also specifies the problem in a third way: by example.

One nonintuitive thing, you might draw your paper first AND last. The last time maybe use an iverted paper (close to black) and `blendMode(ADD)` or `blendMode(SUBTRACT)`, experiment.
I will definitely have to spend more time with blendMode(), I think that would really help the sketch. Thank you!

description:
Found Poem 04.08.22
This screenshot is from a poem I made last semester using only words I found within or in the descriptions of pieces of propaganda from various times in history. I looked through hundreds of pieces in a database I found through the library website, and sequenced phrases and words that stood out to me to make a commentary about the propaganda itself. While it is from a while ago, I wanted to share it here :)

You can see the full poem [here](https://lees846.github.io/found_poem/) and you can read a bit more about the process on my [Learning Portfolio](https://portfolio.newschool.edu/shaylalee/2021/03/02/found-poem-propaganda/)

author: Hasan Khalid
description:
Sketch 1: What happens when you let a computer decide a music composition? 

This is a markov chain implementation using Justin's example code in the chapter. I created a composition on Sunday and I decided to take all of it's arpeggios and use them as strings in the markov chain model. Each note was added as a string in the variables and a model trained. 

The first 30 seconds of the track are the composition created by the markov chain. The second 30 seconds is the composition I came up with.

First 30 seconds has the main lead, supporting arp and bass line created through the markov chain. Main lead is based on a result looped 40 times (also attached in the image). For rhythm its last part repeats. For bass line and supporting arp the loop was carried out 3 times.

The drums are not being controlled by this. (The track is in progress, would not sound the most professional)

comments.comment: This is amazing!

description: Sketch 3: Flowers for Ukraine. Created flower patterns using the Math functions.
code:
<canvas id="myCanvas" resize></canvas>
<script type="text/paperscript" canvas="myCanvas">

  // language paperscript
// require https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/paper.js/0.12.15/paper-full.min.js

var colors = ['yellow','blue']

for (var l = 0; l < 30; l+=2){
for(var v =0; v<40; v++){
 for(var b =0; b<40; b++){   
   
//initial background pattern
// var r1 = new Path.Rectangle(20*(v/2),20*b,Math.sin(60),50);
// r1.fillColor = 'blue'
// r1.rotate(v*15)
   
var r2 = new Path.Rectangle(100*(b/2),100*l/2,Math.tan(b*20),50);   
r2.fillColor =colors[v%2];
r2.rotate(v*Math.sin(100)*50);

var r3 = new Path.Rectangle(100*(b/2),50*l/2,Math.cos(b*40),50);   
r3.fillColor =colors[v%2];
r3.rotate(v*40);
   
//pattern 3 
// var r4 = new Path.Rectangle(100*(b/3),300*l/3,Math.sin(60),40);
// r4.fillColor =colors[v%2];
// r4.rotate(v*20);   

   
function onKeyDown(event) {
  if (event.key === "s") {
    downloadAsSVG();
  }
}

function downloadAsSVG(fileName) {
  // use default name if not provided
  fileName = fileName || "output.svg";

  // create a data url of thes file
  var svgData = project.exportSVG({ asString: true });
  var url = "data:image/svg+xml;utf8," + encodeURIComponent(svgData);

  // create a link to the data, and "click" it
  var link = document.createElement("a");
  link.download = fileName;
  link.href = url;
  link.click();
}

}}}
  
</script>

author: zora wan
description:
## Group 5
**Tool:**
1. Pen or pencil
2. Paper
**Instructions:**
1. Draw a any size square
2. Pick any side of the square and use it as a diagonal to draw the second square.(the diagonal can be =< a side of the square)
3. Pick a side from the second square inside of the first square and repeat step2.
4. Repeat Step3 untill there is no space to draw a new square.

author: Yang ("Zhao Yang") Zhao
description:
Line Challenge 2:
___
Took me quite a long time to figure this out, still not there yet, but really great learning opportunity to revisit `noise`. I honestly think such challenges help me learn faster and deeper about a given concept.

Observations and Strategies 
1. Low amplitude, low frequency
2. increment offset values
3. offset changes back and forth between the bounds 
4. for 3 to happen, need to create negative noise values

description:
My Instructions Set for Group 3:

(1) Draw a shape with three connected lines.

(3) Change colors.
(4) Repeat the last two commands until you reach a shape with 10 connected lines.

author: Shayla Lee
description:
03.02.2022 Experimental Camera II from Advanced Critical Computation. 
I used pixel array manipulation to make a filter that mimics my near-sighted vision. If the user's glasses are on, Teachable Machine recognizes it and the image will be sharper. When the viewer's glasses are off, the filter will blur but be sharper when they are closer to the screen and more blurred when they are further from the screen. Video 2 is the teachable machine model.

My previous Crit Comp filter used get() and ran way too slowly, so this time I knew how to make the code way more efficient with the pixel array! :)

Prototype with checkboxes, not teachable machine: https://editor.p5js.org/lees846/sketches/bS5UExTm7

Final sketch: https://editor.p5js.org/lees846/sketches/wixRkm1kg

author: Shuhan Lei
description:
A poem to mom. In a research I did on mother-daughter relationship laster semester, I asked the participants to complete a fill-in-the-blank poem. I used their answers to build a tracery grammar to generate these poems. 

It's stunning that although these poems are made of parts coming from very different responses, they still resonate and make so much sense. It just tells me how human's complex emotions and understanding can bridge the gaps created by the computer.

author: Erika Bulger
description:
Maltese Folktale Generator - I quickly sketched two of the outputs I liked to give a better idea of what it may entail. 

Interesting tidbit: A lot of pre-Catholic (non-Catholic) Maltese folktales are becoming less and less popular. Though I have Catholic terms (Madonna, St. Paul, etc), I wanted to include some of the cool monster lore they have (more information above in the linked article). As for why the cool folktales are becoming less popular, when I asked my own grandmother about it, she said, "I didn't scare my children with the Babaw because I used God". AKA, rather than saying "If you're bad the Babaw will come and kidnap you", she just had to say, "If you're bad, God will punish you". Both very scarring for children, but at least one is a cryptid/monster tale instead of religious trauma.

More examples of existing Maltese folktales here: https://www.guidememalta.com/en/stranger-things-7-maltese-places-with-famous-legends (I have memories of being told the Ghar Hasan one as a kid).

Code can be found here: https://editor.p5js.org/erikabulger/full/eLcrkcWvC
inspiration_name: 9 Maltese Monsters Straight Out Of Your Nightmares
code:
let outputP;
let genButton;

function setup() {
  noCanvas();
  background(255);
  textAlign(LEFT, TOP);
  textSize(24);
  genButton = createButton("Click to Generate a Maltese Folktale");
  genButton.mousePressed(generate);
  outputP = createP("");
}

function draw() {}

function generate() {
  var grammar = tracery.createGrammar(grammarSource);
  grammar.addModifiers(tracery.baseEngModifiers);
  var output = grammar.flatten("#origin#");
  outputP.html(output);
}

author: Shuhan Lei
description:
I experimented with various randomness tactics with these bamboo sketches, the codes for which randomly generate different lighting situations and the arrangements (placement, thickness, angle) of the bamboo shoots. 

To add more control over the overall aesthetic and to create a sense of depth, I divided the bamboos into three groups (back, middle and front), and assigned each of them a different range of random values for each property (distance, thickness, color & tilted degree). I also tried out the high/low bias functions, and yet only saw a very subtle change in the effect -- perhaps because there're too many layers to the image and the number of instances isn't great enough to see a huge difference.

I could possibly add more elements to the image in the future to see a greater contrast between the different biased distributions.

description: Sketch 4: Animating with paperJs. Try clicking multiple Keys at a time and see how the bubbles appear and disappear! If I have more time later, I will develop this further.
code:
<canvas id="myCanvas" resize></canvas>
<script type="text/paperscript" canvas="myCanvas">

  // language paperscript
// require https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/paper.js/0.12.15/paper-full.min.js
// tutorial video from: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ym1zR0lPbhE 
  
//array of circles, when pressed we put it in an array
var circles = [];
  
function onKeyDown(event){
  var maxPoint = new Point(view.size.width, view.size.height);
  var randomPoint = Point.random();
  var point = maxPoint*randomPoint;
  var newCircle = new Path.Circle(point,400);
  newCircle.fillColor = "pink";
  circles.push(newCircle);
  // code below doesnt work because it will push PINK into array
  // circles.push(new Path.Circle(point,20).fillColor ="pink");
}
  
// var animatedCircle = new Path.Circle(new Point(300,300),100);
// animatedCircle.fillColor = "orange";
  
//animation, will run on every frame of animation 
function onFrame(event){
  for (var i = 0; i < circles.length; i++){
    //loop through all the circles in array and we change color in every frame 
    circles[i].fillColor.hue +=1;
    circles[i].scale(.99);
    circles[i].blendMode = "multiply";
  //animation request a new frame, the color changes
  // animatedCircle.fillColor.hue += 1; 
  }
  //scale the circle down every frame
  // animatedCircle.scale(.99);
}
</script>

author: Beatriz Ribeiro
description:
Have you played World of Warcraft (or any MMORPG really)? It's just so draining to decide your character's name... You have to consider race, class, and humongous lore... So I wanted to create a character name generator based on the rules of the world. For this race, the Khul Tiras, the sturdy sailors of the alliance, you get their title, name, last/family name, and even a lore line. 

- By lore, their first names are based in old English names. They are humans, after all. 
- Then their last name/family name is always related to the ocean, sailors, boats and so on.
- Their titles follow the current possible titles within the faction.
- Then a storyline. Something that will inspire the player to think about their character's background.
inspiration_name: Kul Tiras from World of Warcraft

author: Justin Bakse
description:
My second pass at this. The first time I stumbled on using `blendMode(MULTIPLY)` for all the strokes and liked how it built up like marker on paper and was looking at all the other marker sketches.

This time I tried to really lean in to the marker look. I added some more random mistakes, made sure the blue never built up to full black, and put in some paper grain and a sort of lighting vignette.

Its all pretty subtle, changing the output maybe 10% and probably took about 3 times as long as the original sketch.

comments.comment: The marker look is really deceptive!

This is awesome!
> for (let n = 0; n < **3000000**; n++)
@Lauria Yeah! Let the computer do some work!
the day i code 200+ lines in 1.5h I'll tattoo HACKER MODE on my forehead. also... that marker effect is amazing.
This is really awesome. I noticed many uses of modern JS operators that I just learned and haven't really applied. Quite a great reference piece!

author: Lauria Clarke
Erika Bulger
description: My take on the face generator project - a Prehistoric Maltese Idol Generator. Recently, I've been thinking a lot about pre-Christian vs post-Christian Malta. More specifically, how the Christian Inquisition & Knights of St. John worked hard to wipe out existing "pagan" customs and beliefs, and how they even went so far as to destroy existing proof of other religions in Malta (not just early religions, but even Islam and Judaism). This idol generator implies "deity" generator, since these fragments of statues are all we have left of the prehistoric belief system. Perhaps they symbolize Astarte or another Carthaginian/Phoenician deity? We will never know (which drives me nuts!). Code can be found here: https://editor.p5js.org/erikabulger/full/kltMVbpN8

author: Cheryl Huang
description: I was having fun to learn this in p5js. And I added a little my own twist that I thought matching better with the sound:)
code:
let txts = []
let ft
let sentence = "THE NEW WORLD DIMENSION | THE NEW WORLD DIMENSION | THE NEW WORLD DIMENSION | THE NEW WORLD DIMENSION | THE NEW WORLD DIMENSION"
let webGLGraphics

let overAllTexture
let bgm
function preload(){
	ft = loadFont("SpaceMono-BoldItalic.ttf")
	bgm = loadSound("201102 New Dimensions.mp3")
}
function setup() {
	createCanvas(1000,1000);
	pixelDensity(2)
	webGLGraphics = createGraphics(width,height,WEBGL);
	textFont(ft)
	let textureHeight = 500
	for(var i=0;i<5;i++){
		txts[i] = createGraphics(1200,textureHeight)
		txts[i].pixelDensity(2)
		txts[i].textFont(ft)
		// txts[i].clear(0,0,1000,500)
		txts[i].fill([0,0,0,255][i%4])
		txts[i].strokeWeight(2)
		let spanWidth = i*2+1
		txts[i].rect(0,250-spanWidth,1180,spanWidth*2)
		txts[i].fill(0)
		txts[i].text(sentence,0,textureHeight/2+25)
        
 
	}
	webGLGraphics.background(255);
	background(0)
	
	
	// noprotect
	overAllTexture=createGraphics(width,height)
	overAllTexture.loadPixels()
	// noStroke()
	for(var i=0;i<width+50;i++){
		for(var o=0;o<height+50;o++){
			overAllTexture.set(i,o,color(100,noise(i/30,o/30,i*o/50)*random([0,20,40,120])))
		}
	}
	overAllTexture.updatePixels()
	bgm.loop()
	bgm.play()
	
}



function draw() {
	webGLGraphics.push()
	webGLGraphics.clear(0,0,width,height)
	webGLGraphics.fill(0)
	webGLGraphics.rotateX(sin(frameCount/100 + mouseX/100))
	webGLGraphics.rotateY(cos(frameCount/50+ mouseY/100) )
	webGLGraphics.rotateZ(cos(frameCount/50))
	webGLGraphics.stroke(0)
	
	webGLGraphics.noFill()
	webGLGraphics.box(20)
	webGLGraphics.noStroke()
	for(var i=0;i<15;i++){
		webGLGraphics.push()
			webGLGraphics.texture(txts[i%5])
			webGLGraphics.rotateX(sin(frameCount/200+i))
			webGLGraphics.rotateY(cos(frameCount/100+i*5))
			webGLGraphics.rotateZ(cos(frameCount/100+i*3))
			webGLGraphics.sphere(250+i*10 + noise(i,frameCount/50)*20,64)
		webGLGraphics.pop()
	}
	webGLGraphics.pop()
	
	clear(0,0,width,height)
	fill(random([0, 250]), random([0, 100]), random([100, 200]), 255);
	rect(0,0,width,height)
	image(webGLGraphics,0,0)
	fill(0)
	noStroke()
	textFont(ft)
	textSize(20)
	text("ROTATE X: "+sin(frameCount/200+i) + "\n"
			 +"ROTATE Y: "+cos(frameCount/100+i*5) + "\n"
			 +"ROTATE Z: "+cos(frameCount/100+i*3) + "\n"
			 	, 40,height-100)
	stroke(0)
	noFill()
	push()
	strokeWeight(2)
	rect(20,20,width-40,height-40)
	pop()
	push()
		blendMode(MULTIPLY)
		image(overAllTexture,0,0)
	pop()
	// ellipse(mouseX, mouseY, 20, 20);
}

This looks so cool! 
But I think that is something wrong in the 40th line of the code because it's not loading.

author: Nicky  Fuganjananon
description: Sketch 1: Playing with paperJs for the first time. Trying to understand the new commands and language. Used for statement to try to create flower shapes. Manipulated it further (image 2) with wonky shapes. The SVG file was really easy to play with on AI. Updated last image with blendmode
code:
<canvas id="myCanvas" resize></canvas>
<script type="text/paperscript" canvas="myCanvas">

  // language paperscript
// require https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/paper.js/0.12.15/paper-full.min.js
var colors = ['green','blue','white','grey','yellow']
var rectNum = 30

var rect_bounds = new Rectangle(new Point(0, 0), new Point(500, 500));
var rect_path = new Path.Rectangle(rect_bounds);
rect_path.fillColor = "#333";
  

for (var i = 0; i < rectNum; i++){
  var bounds = new Rectangle(new Point(225,225), new Point(300,300));
  var path = new Path.Rectangle(bounds);
  path.fillColor = colors[i%4];
  var scale = (1-i/rectNum)*2.5;
  path.scale(scale);
  path.rotate(i*20);
}

function onKeyDown(event) {
  if (event.key === "s") {
    downloadAsSVG();
  }
}

function downloadAsSVG(fileName) {
  // use default name if not provided
  fileName = fileName || "output.svg";

  // create a data url of thes file
  var svgData = project.exportSVG({ asString: true });
  var url = "data:image/svg+xml;utf8," + encodeURIComponent(svgData);

  // create a link to the data, and "click" it
  var link = document.createElement("a");
  link.download = fileName;
  link.href = url;
  link.click();
}

</script>

author: Erika Bulger
description: I used an old black-and-white photo of my Maltese ancestors and had a spiral motion slowly draw out the pixels over time. When thinking about my Maltese ancestry, I often think about spirals (repetition of traditions, belief systems, repetition of generational trauma). Also, because a lot of old neolithic Maltese art have a spiral motif. I also made it so that the eldest in the picture is at the center, my biz-biz-nunna.
inspiration_name: SPIRAL DESIGNS ON STONE SLABS FROM THE TEMPLES

comments.comment: So beautiful!
